docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Finally, a Health Bill'' (editorial, July 27) indicates that the noble efforts of President Clinton (and intensive explorations of Hillary Rodham Clinton) in 1993 to achieve universal health care for Americans ended as his ''greatest legislative fiasco.''

headline.main: Where Is Our Political Courage on Health Care?

docs.lead_paragraph: Four years ago, candidate Bill Clinton issued a ringing promise to ''end welfare as we know it,'' to ''empower people with the education, training and child care they need'' to escape the trap of dependency. As President, he proposed to increase welfare spending by $10 billion to accomplish those goals. On Wednesday, Mr. Clinton stood at a lectern in the White House and said somberly that he would sign Republican welfare legislation that would cut nearly $55 billion in spending and give states vast new powers to remove people from welfare rolls.

headline.main: Clinton's Welfare Shift Ends Tortuous Journey

docs.abstract: Sixth article in The Clinton Record, a series on Pres Clinton's four years in office, focuses on welfare policy; Clinton's decision to sign Republicans' welfare-reform bill, most sweeping reversal of domestic social policy since New Deal, represents remarkable reversal from vision of welfare he outlined in 1992, when he proposed to increase welfare spending by $10 billion to accomplish goal to 'end welfare as we know it'; marks end of tortuous four-year journey that, in may ways, is emblematic of way in which Clinton has often defied orthodoxies of his party; even some of his critics give him credit for establishing national dialogue on welfare that put issue on political agenda and resulted in overhaul that was all but unimaginable during 12 years of Republican control of White House; photos; charts (L)

byline.original: By PETER T. KILBORN and SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

docs.lead_paragraph: After nearly six hours of emotional debate, the House today approved a bill that would make English the official language of the United States. The vote was 259 to 169, with 223 Republicans and 36 Democrats favoring the bill, and 8 Republicans, 160 Democrats and 1 independent opposing it.

headline.main: House Approves Measure On Official U.S. Language
headline.kicker: House Approves Measure On Official U.S. Language

docs.abstract: House, by 259 to 169 vote, approves bill that would make English official language of US (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years after comprehensive national health insurance died in Congress, House and Senate leaders announced agreement on legislation that would allow workers to take health insurance from job to job.

docs.lead_paragraph: THEY are being given time they never imagined they would have for the journey. Now all they have to figure out is where they are going. People with AIDS whose lives are being extended through new drug therapies are hearing terms like ''chronic manageable disease'' for the first time. And many are facing decisions they once thought they might escape. Professional choices that were moot now seem pressing. Complex and expensive medical regimes loom. Nest eggs that were being spent are again being conserved for the long term.
docs.abstract: Development of drugs that can greatly extend the lives of people with AIDS is forcing them to confront questions about their careers, their long-term medical treatment, financial future and even retirement--things they did not think about when they faced the prospect of imminent death; a readjustment of such magnitude is wrenching, no matter how welcome; photos (M)

A1 SAUDIS TO AID TROOP MOVE The United States and Saudi Arabia agreed to split the cost of moving American soldiers stationed in Saudi Arabia to other bases to protect them from terrorist attacks. A3 JAPAN ACTS ON FOOD POISONING Stepping up its fight against outbreaks of food poisoning, Japan's Government has resorted to a law giving it emergency powers to set up quarantines. A6 ISRAELI-P.L.O DEAL CONFIRMED The previous Israeli Government and Palestinians had secretly reached a blueprint for a peace accord that included a Palestinian state with its capital outside Jerusalem, a negotiator said. A8 IRAQ OIL SALES STYMIED United Nations officials said the United States blocked agreement on procedures opening the way for emergency sales of oil by Iraq. A8 BOSNIA'S OTHER VICTIMS The wounded and paralyzed from the war around Sarajevo say that, as the city adjusts to peace, they are treated like outcasts, left in institutions or at home without help. A10 At least 15 died in a stampede at a South African railway station. A3 Bavarian lawmakers tightened restrictions on abortion. A4 African leaders agreed to impose sanctions on Burundi. A8 London Journal: Noses twitched in vain at rare plant's opening. A4 National A12-25,D22 CLINTON TO SIGN WELFARE BILL President Clinton said that he would sign the latest version of welfare legislation in Congress, even though the bill would reverse six decades of social welfare policy. A1 BEFORE THE ANNOUNCEMENT Mr. Clinton's move capped years of work on the issue, months of legislative back-and-forth with Congress and thousands of hours of wrenching policy debate within the Administration itself. A1 FEAR OF LOCAL COSTS Mr. Clinton's announcement left local officials and welfare advocates gasping at the enormous new costs they say will have to be borne by city and state taxpayers. A1 Welfare recipients elicited little surprise after the move. A23 Governors generally welcomed the President's decision. A23 The move brought deep dismay from advocates for the poor. A23 News analysis: Bob Dole has been deprived of a campaign issue. A25 CLINTON'S RECORD ON CRIME The President has scrapped his party's traditional approach to crime and criminal justice, embracing punitive measures that have given him conservative credentials. A1 Mr. Clinton has not filled the judiciary with liberal members. A20 COUGH VACCINE APPROVED The Government approved a vaccine for whooping cough in infants that is less likely than the current vaccine to cause side effects. A12 HOME SEARCHED IN ATLANTA Federal investigators conducted a search of the Atlanta apartment belonging to the security guard who has gone from hero to suspect in the Olympic bombing. A12 Many news executives went against their policies on suspects. A12 FIGHT ON ABORTION PLANK Two governors said they would press delegates at the Republican convention to substitute the party's current anti-abortion plank. A16 WASTE SITE MEASURE ADVANCES The Senate approved a measure to establish an interim nuclear waste storage site in Nevada. A18 CHALLENGE FROM LAWYERS A prominent civil liberties lawyer is challenging the constitutionality of the measure requiring legal services lawyers to withdraw from class-action lawsuits. D22 MOVEMENT ON INSURANCE BILL Leaders in Congress announced agreement on legislation that would allow workers to take their health insurance from job to job. docs.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers Advance On Health Insurance House and Senate leaders reached an agreement on legislation that would let workers take their health insurance coverage from job to job. Supporters contend that the measure, by curbing exclusions from coverage because of pre-existing medical conditions, would free 25 million to 30 million Americans from the fear of losing health insurance if they changed jobs. The bill also allows the creation of as many as 750,000 tax-sheltered Medical Savings Accounts. $(Page D22.$) House and Senate negotiators agreed to a rise in the Federal minimum wage to $5.15 an hour, virtually assuring a 90-cent increase for 10 million Americans. $(D22.$) Microsoft Predicts Strong Future Microsoft executives told analysts that the company was not only prepared to deal with changes brought about by the Internet but would also use the Internet to accelerate growth, despite competition from such powerful rivals as Sun Microsystems and Netscape Communications. $(D2.$) Blue Chips Advance Strongly Stocks, especially blue chips, advanced strongly, as interest rates fell on signs of softness in manufacturing. The Dow industrials rose 46.98 points, to 5,528.91, while the Nasdaq composite rose 8.64, to 1,080.59, as technology shares strengthened. $(D8.$) Prices of Treasury securities rose sharply, pushing the long bond's yield down to 6.97 percent, from 7.03 percent on Tuesday. $(D18.$) Air Crash Highlights Niche Company The crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 has shed light on a tiny niche company in the aviation business -- Megadata, which provides data on air traffic patterns for the industry. $(D4.$) Whooping Cough Vaccine Approved The F.D.A. approved a vaccine to prevent whooping cough in infants that has fewer side effects than the current vaccine. Connaught makes the vaccine, Tripedia, which is already used for booster shots. $(A12.$) U.S. Blocks Iraqi Oil Sales The U.S. blocked agreement in the United Nations on procedures for as much as $2 billion of emergency Iraqi oil sales to pay for food and relief supplies, but did not give a reason for its move. $(A8.$) Sony's Earnings Double Sony reported its earnings more than doubled to 17.10 billion yen, or $156.8 million, exceeding expectations, as worldwide sales rose 30.6 percent, helped by the yen's fall. $(D2.$) Silicon Graphics President Resigns Thomas A. Jermoluk resigned as president of Silicon Graphics to become head of @Home, a California start-up that is developing technology to deliver Internet access over cable television lines. $(D4.$) Jeep Owners Go to Camp Chrysler is inviting Jeep owners to come to camp for two days this summer as part of an effort to appeal to the buyers' life styles. It is the latest example of auto makers' reliance on relationship marketing. Advertising. $(D6.$) Viacom Reports Lower Earnings Viacom said that profit in the second quarter fell more than 22 percent, reflecting lower programming revenue. $(D6.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years after comprehensive national health insurance died in Congress, House and Senate leaders tonight announced agreement on legislation that would allow workers to take their health insurance coverage from job to job. Supporters contend it would free 25 million to 30 million Americans who have pre-existing medical problems from fear of losing health insurance if they change jobs.

headline.main: Pact Would Allow Workers To Retain Health Benefits

docs.abstract: House and Senate leaders agree on bill to let workers take their health insurance with them when they change jobs; co-sponsors Sen Edward M Kennedy and Sen Nancy Landon Kassebaum comment, news conference; bill curbs exclusions from coverage because of pre-existing medical conditions; bill also allows creation of up to 750,000 tax-sheltered medical savings accounts on experimental basis (M)
